title: Master Harold… and the Boys, National’s Lyttelton Theatre, review: a spellbinding affirmation of the need for humanity at the bleakest moments
text:
A 1982 New Yorker profile of Athol Fugard, assessing his huge contribution to relaying the injustices of Apartheid, suggested that the South African playwright deserved the Nobel Prize in Literature and the Nobel Peace Prize as well. Its author, the American critic Mel Gussow, wrote: “[Fugard] wears his South African citizenship as a hair shirt, and each of his plays is a cry of mea culpa.”

None of his many plays, though, emits that guilty remorse more emphatically or piercingly than Master Harold… and the Boys, which made its premiere that year on Broadway. In it, Fugard – still with us at 87 – reproduced an incident from his hard-up youth in Port Elizabeth that most writers would have wanted...
